docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers said the experimental treatment kept monkeys alive in a study even after the Marburg virus was already detectable in the animals’ blood.

headline.main: Experimental Drug Used for Ebola-Related Virus Shows Promise
headline.print_headline: Experimental Drug Used for Ebola-Related Virus Shows Promise

docs.abstract: Researchers report experimental drug being developed by Tekmira Pharmaceuticals has completely protected monkeys from lethal doses of Marburg virus; study bolsters confidence that similar medicine might be effective if deployed in current Ebola outbreak in Africa.
docs.snippet: Researchers said the experimental treatment kept monkeys alive in a study even after the Marburg virus was already detectable in the animals’ blood.

docs.lead_paragraph: Why aren’t doctors promoting the lifesaving HPV vaccine?
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by pediatrics Prof Paul A Offit contends thousands of American women and men die of cancers that can be prevented with human papillomavirus vaccine because doctors do not want to talk about sex; underscores how dangerous HPV can be, and how dangerous it is to fail to administer vaccine to adolescents.
docs.snippet: Why aren’t doctors promoting the lifesaving HPV vaccine?

docs.lead_paragraph: A scary problem lurks beyond the frenzied efforts to keep people from spreading Ebola: No one knows exactly where the virus comes from or how to stop it from seeding new outbreaks.

headline.main: Another Ebola Problem: Finding Its Natural Source
headline.print_headline: Another Ebola Problem: Finding Its Natural Source

docs.snippet: A scary problem lurks beyond the frenzied efforts to keep people from spreading Ebola: No one knows exactly where the virus comes from or how to stop it from seeding new outbreaks.

docs.lead_paragraph: The departure of many Western development workers from the West African countries hit hardest by Ebola has further weakened the region’s decrepit, understaffed health systems.

headline.main: With Aid Doctors Gone, Ebola Fight Grows Harder
headline.print_headline: As Many Doctors Retreat, Ebola Fight Grows Harder

docs.abstract: Departure of many Western development workers from West African countries hit hardest by Ebola virus has further weakened region's understaffed health systems during one of the most volatile health crises ever; international organizations, wealthy countries and charitable groups gear up to fight outbreak but the absence of doctors and volunteers in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone is reminder of the daunting practical obstacles.
docs.snippet: The departure of many Western development workers from the West African countries hit hardest by Ebola has further weakened the region’s decrepit, understaffed health systems.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some doctors say outfits worn by caregivers need to be more protective than what the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends.

headline.main: Hospitals in the U.S. Get Ready for Ebola
headline.print_headline: Hospitals in the U.S. Get Ready for Ebola

docs.abstract: Hospitals across United States are rushing to prepare for first traveler from West Africa arriving in emergency room with symptoms of infection from Ebola virus; some hospitals are going beyond recommended guidelines to avoid spread of infection.
docs.snippet: Some doctors say outfits worn by caregivers need to be more protective than what the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends.
